<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 117, 379, 144]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 170, 183, 187]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 193, 332, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice (Core)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 246, 507, 263]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 277, 437, 293]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[215, 291, 539, 320]]<|/det|>
Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 338, 228, 353]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 354, 912, 522]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.- For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Write in soft pencil.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.- Do not use correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- Take the weight of \(1.0 \text{kg}\) to be \(10 \text{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10 \text{m/s}^2\)).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 549, 220, 564]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 565, 806, 615]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer.- Any rough working should be done on this question paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 297, 138, 315]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 297, 235, 315]]<|/det|> at point P <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 323, 138, 341]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 323, 237, 341]]<|/det|> at point Q <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 350, 138, 368]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 350, 237, 368]]<|/det|> at point R <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 375, 133, 393]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 375, 437, 393]]<|/det|> it is the same at points P, Q and R <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 419, 106, 437]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 419, 922, 452]]<|/det|> Which statement correctly compares the production of electricity using wind and the production of electricity using nuclear fission? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 462, 133, 480]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 462, 861, 480]]<|/det|> Wind is less reliable than nuclear fission; both wind and nuclear fission are renewable. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 488, 131, 507]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 488, 856, 505]]<|/det|> Wind is less reliable than nuclear fission; wind is renewable, but nuclear fission is not. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 515, 131, 533]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 515, 870, 532]]<|/det|> Wind is more reliable than nuclear fission; both wind and nuclear fission are renewable. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 540, 133, 559]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 540, 866, 558]]<|/det|> Wind is more reliable than nuclear fission; wind is renewable, but nuclear fission is not. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 585, 104, 603]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 585, 781, 603]]<|/det|> To calculate the power produced by a force, the size of the force must be known. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 615, 559, 632]]<|/det|> What else needs to be known to calculate the power? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 617, 920, 650]]<|/det|>

air temperatureair density
